title: Will the United States experience two consecutive quarters of a negative real GDP growth rate in 2019?
preds: The 3rd estimate of Q3 GDP came out this morning at 2.1%...unchanged since the last estimate.  I cannot see how there can possibly be two consecutive quarters of negative real GDP growth this year.
Dropping to zero because there's only a couple weeks left.

The unemployment rate ticked back down to its lowest level in nearly half a century and wage gains remained near their strongest in a decade, the Labor Department’s closely watched monthly employment report showed on Friday (Para. 1-2). It is unlikely at this juncture.

Yesterday the Commerce Department reported that real GDP for Q3 rose 2.1%, up from and earlier estimate of 1.9%.  I always dislike using the word "impossible," but it seems to be impossible that we can have two consecutive quarters of negative real GDP growth in 2019.

The Conference Board has weighed in that Q3 growth was 1.9%.  Along with the New York, Atlanta, and St Louis Feds all showing positive Q3 growth, two consecutive quarters of negative real GDP rate in 2019 is about as close to impossible as can be.
It is now October.  This ship has sailed.
Updating due to passage of time.  I find it almost unimaginable that Q3 will be revised down into negative numbers, but the Brier score has almost 0 upside going from 5% to 0%.
Q3 growth of 1.9% making it impossible to have two consecutive quarters of negative growth in 2019. https://www.cnbc.com/2019/10/30/us-gdp-q3-2019-first-reading.html
Three quarters have finished.  There is only one left; thus, it is now impossible.

Advance estimates of Q3 growth have been released showing 1.9%. It's logically impossible for this forecast to be true if Q3 growth is not revised downward by enough to become negative, and a revision downward of two whole points would be unprecedented.

The first estimate of Q3 GDP came out yesterday at 1.9% and was described as "solid."   Of note (from Econoday): "The good news is that strength is squarely centered in the most important component, and that's real consumer spending which rose at a 2.9 percent pace despite a very tough comparison with the second quarter's unusually strong 4.6 percent showing. And within consumer spending, durable goods continue to post very sharp growth at a 7.6 percent rate versus 13.0 percent in the second quarter with both quarters showing especially strong results for recreational goods & vehicles. This speaks to discretionary strength at the consumer level." It is now next to impossible to imagine two consecutive quarters of negative real GDP growth in 2019.

With the advance estimate for Q3 GDP reported today at 1.9% [1], the only chance of two quarters of consecutive negative growth would require a massive downward revision to previous quarters, which seems unlikely.  I am revising my probability of a recession in 2019 to 1%.   [1] https://www.bea.gov/index.php/news/2019/gross-domestic-product-3rd-quarter-2019-advance-estimate

Third quarter GDP advance print just released this morning at 1.9%.  It would take a massive unexpected revision to send this print lower and into negative growth for the quarter.  Therefore I am changing my forecast of a recession in 2019 to 0%.
The economy has slowed, but the growth rate is not negative for the third quarter.  It is also unlikely it will be negative for the fourth quarter.

Consumer spending is the work horse of GDP.  Last week's jobless claims were slightly below the consensus estimate, and consumer sentiment was high (95.5) and within the consensus range.  Although September existing home sales fell a bit, they fell from an unusually high previous month's sales.  Hard to see Q3 being negative.

Growth has been positive Q1 and Q2, meaning this can only be true if growth is negative for both Q3 and Q4. Q3 monthly results have manufacturing indices up [1], unemployment down [2], markets somewhat up [3]. Hard to see negative growth in Q3, which means hard to see this happening. Gross Domestic Product, 3rd quarter 2018 (third estimate); Corporate Profits, 3rd quarter 2018 (revised estimate) Real gross domestic product (GDP) increased at an annual rate of 3.4 percent in the third quarter of 2018 (table 1), according to the "third" estimate released by the Bureau of Economic Analysis. In the second quarter, real GDP increased 4.2 percent. The GDP estimate released today is based on more complete source data than were available for the "second" estimate issued last month. In the second estimate, the increase in real GDP was 3.5 percent. With this third estimate for the third quarter, personal consumption expenditures (PCE) and exports were revised down, and private inventory investment was revised up; the general picture of economic growth remains the same (see "Updates to GDP" on page 2). Real gross domestic income (GDI) increased 4.3 percent in the third quarter, compared with an increase of 0.9 percent in the second quarter. The average of real GDP and real GDI, a supplemental measure of U.S. economic activity that equally weights GDP and GDI, increased 3.8 percent in the third quarter, compared with an increase of 2.5 percent in the second quarter (table 1). The increase in real GDP in the third quarter reflected positive contributions from PCE, private inventory investment, nonresidential fixed investment, federal government spending, and state and local government spending that were partly offset by negative contributions from exports and residential fixed investment. Imports, which are a subtraction in the calculation of GDP, increased (table 2). Release Dates in 2019

As the US economy grew in Q1 and Q2, the only way for this question to be answered Yes would be if it shrank in both Q3 and Q4. 
Inside view: most economists predict continued slow growth: https://www.marketwatch.com/story/second-quarter-us-gdp-left-at-2-downshifting-economy-unlikely-to-rev-up-soon-2019-09-26
Outside view: charts available at https://www.ceicdata.com/en/indicator/united-states/real-gdp-growth show there is a long term decline in growth (it hasn't gone past 5% since 2000). But the chart never goes from over 2% in one quarter to less than 0 in the next - it would be more of a gradual dip that continues below zero. So I put chance of negative growth in Q3 at 5%. 
From the historical data since 1948, a first quarter of negative growth is followed by a second quarter of negative growth 37.5% of the time.
So the combined probability of Q3 and Q4 being negative would be 5% * 37.5%, or 1.875%.

Consumer spending is the 800 pound gorilla of GDP.  Last week jobless claims were down, consumer sentiment rose, and retail sales were at the top of the consensus range.  Furthermore, three regional Fed real GDP nowcasts were positive.  It is extremely difficult to see this quarter being negative, and this quarter would have to be negative in order to have two consecutive quarters of negative real GDP growth.

The Federal Reserve is poised to deliver another rate cut Riley and Goldman (2019) Sept. 15, stated that: The US Federal Reserve looks set to follow the European Central Bank, and cut rates next week by perhaps a quarter of a percentage point. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell has made clear that he doesn't think a US recession is likely, but he has acknowledged that economic headwinds are intensifying. 
"There are all these risks, and we're monitoring them very carefully and we're conducting policy in a way that will address them," he said earlier this month. 
The comments helped bolster investor expectations that a rate cut will be announced following the central bank's meeting on September 17 and 18. The Fed slashed interest rates for the first time in a decade in July as the cost of the US-China trade war mounted.
"The domestically focused, consumer-orientated parts of the economy are holding up, but with inflation looking non-threatening the Federal Reserve has scope to offer support to the economy," wrote analysts at ING, a Dutch bank (Para. 1-3). Riley, C. & Goldman, D. (2019). The Federal Reserve is poised to deliver another rate cut. CNN. Business. Sept. 15, 2019. Retrieved from

The main path to negative growth in the short term would be a big turndown in consumer spending. It is very unlikely that the tariffs will result in this in the 3rd quarter. There may even be a spending increase to get ahead of larger tariffs later. The effects of global economic slowing will also not affect the US in time for 3rd quarter negative growth

There are only two quarters left, and no previous quarter has been negative, the Fed has already provided some stimulus and the US economy is currently in good shape with consumer spending supported by low unemployment. There are serious headwinds which may cause a slowdown or even a recession, such as the hit to business confidence and problems in the manufacturing and farming sectors, but this is more likely to occur in 2020, since the economy may slow to a halt rather than stop suddenly as firms try to hold out as long as possible.
Therefore I do not see a technical recession for 2019 but the risk for 2020 is greater, particularly since the trade war shows no genuine signs of abating and the US government lacks the competency to formulate an effective fiscal response. In addition, despite the Fed having some remaining ammunition, a primary driver of the recent slump in business confidence is uncertainty over trade policy. In these circumstances, monetary policy may not be as effective because even with lower interest rates, firms may not want to invest if they think they are going to lose access to their markets over night. However, I have put a 2% probability because 'never say never'. There may be more unseen shocks in the pipeline which could exacerbate the current circumstances.

The base rate of this occurring per year is around 6%, estimated by its annual occurrence between 1987 and 2018 (a period of relatively internally consistent monetary policy and economic factors). I adjust downward from here according to the fact that both quarterly GDP growth is highly autocorrelated and Q2 growth was 2%, and that the Atlanta Fed GDPNow forecast for Q3 is around 2%, where average absolute error for that at this point in a nowcast period is around 1%.

Latest Survey of Professional Forecasters numbers came in and out the combined probability of the last two quarters of 2019 being negative at less than 3%. A lot is being made of the recent yield curve inversions, but a few thoughts on that:
1. Interesting series of WSJ articles pointed out that a majority of moves in long dated Treasuries were systematic flows to cover duration gaps and negative convexity positions
2. The yield curve on average has preceded a recession by about 10 months (range of 5 to 17)
3. I disagree with the “this time is different” and “QE has distorted markets” arguments. I see the risks primarily on the long end of the range in bullet two Trade war escalation is concerning, but given all the movement down recently, it seems like the “Trump Negotiating Cycle” is due to rebound. Even if it doesn’t employment and consumer spending will have to take a serious hit before negative GDP growth kicks in. Let’s not forget that the SP500 is still up 18% in 2019 so the wealth effect is alive and well.  I’m expecting a continued slowing in global growth, slowing manufacturing and business investment in the US, Fed stimulus in the form of at least 2 more rate cuts this year, and a resilient US consumer that will see wages tick up slightly due to labor market competitiveness that will offset some tariff impacts. Overall, expecting core PCE in the 1.5-2.1 range - doesn’t get feel like an economy in full-blown recession.

Franck (2010) Aug 22, states that: The main part of the yield curve inverted once again Thursday as the yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note traded under that of the 2-year note, the third time the recession indicator has been triggered since last Wednesday (Para. 1). The move came after Kansas City Federal Reserve President Esther George and Philadelphia Fed President Patrick Harker told CNBC that they don’t see the case for additional interest rate cuts after the central’s bank quarter-point reduction in July. The initial inversion on Thursday followed in the immediate aftermath of George’s comments, though the spread between the two yield bounced into and out of negative territory throughout the rest of the trading session. As of 4:05 p.m. ET the curve was inverted with the 2-year Treasury yield at 1.614%, above the 10-year at 1.611%. Such an inversion is viewed by many fixed-income traders as a sign of a future recession, though forecasting the timing of an eventual downturn is a tougher task (Para 1-4). Franck, T. (2019). Yield curve inverts once again on fears the Fed won’t save the economy. CNBC. Bonds. Aug. 22 2019
https://www.cnbc.com/2019/08/22/us-bonds-treasury-yields-tick-higher-ahead-of-jackson-hole-symposium.html Fitzgerald, M. (2019). Esther George says the Fed’s ‘large balance sheet’ may have helped cause the yield curve inversion. Federal Reserve. Aug. 22, 2019. Retrieved from
https://www.cnbc.com/2019/08/22/esther-george-says-the-feds-large-balance-sheet-may-have-helped-cause-the-yield-curve-inversion.html KEY POINTS
•	“I think the Fed still has a large balance sheet, and that could be putting some downward pressure on those longer-term rates,” Kansas City Fed President Ester George said Thursday.
•	The central bank’s balance sheet, which stands at around $3.8 trillion of mostly Treasurys and mortgage-backed securities, ballooned to as much as $4.5 trillion as the Fed sought to stimulate the economy out of the financial crisis.
•	George also said she does not see the U.S. getting sucked into the global trend of negative-yielding government bonds.

Warning signs about the end of this period of economic expansion are beginning to appear. Yields on the 10 year T note continue to be suppressed as capital flight from the stock markets accelerates in the face of increased market volatility. The global economy is also slowing. Production at Chinese factories is at a 17-year low and it appears the German economy is headed into recession (they've had 1 quarter of negative growth, with this quarter slated to be worse. The only reason this forecast score isn't higher is the rather short time frame. While the US economy is slowing, and businesses are cautious, unemployment remains very low and consumer confidence is high. Given the huge impact consumer spending has on the economy, continued strong buying could buoy the flagging economy enough to eke out incremental growth for the remainder of 2019.

But on balance, 2 consecutive quarters of negative (quarter-on-quarter) real GDP growth remains low.

My notes: this question is all about timing: will Q3 GDP growth be negative? The GDP trend is downward but as of now still mostly pointing to positive current conditions. However, we're just seeing data from mid Q2 at this point. 3.2% GDP growth in Q1; ~1-1.5% in Q2. <0% in Q3 is not out of the question. Bottom line: the trend is close enough that I need to consider whether some external factor (like tariffs on Mexican goods, major natural disaster big enough to move GDP, some new geopolitical instability, etc) push the trend lower sharply in time to cause Q2 to be negative. So let's think about that: It would need to be before the 1st half of September (for a really huge event):
1) 5%: I think the tariffs are the biggest threat that could cause Q3 to be negative: => i think this is mostly already appearing in the numbers, but we need to factor in the effect of the threat of Mexican tariffs. Even if they don't go into effect, there is the 
      Exports + imports = ~27% of GDP. Let's assume they slowed down aggregate import/export volume by the equivalent of 1 day (longer delays at border, economic costs). ~1.1% impact on GDP. That's enough to push us into recession in Q3 (and what we're observing now). SO the question is whether the administration will continue on this course in the face of evidence that it is putting the economy at risk. I don't think they would do this intentionally, but I could see miscalculations leading to this outcome especially associated with some unexpected external trigger. =>30% 
2) 1%: A related factor is slowing immigration into the US. probably not sudden or significant enough to move the trend much between now and Q3. Offset by increasing government deficit spending.
3) 2%: major natural disaster. Hurricane season is expected to be near average. Big Earthquakes are on the order of 1% / year. Major forest fire: hard to envision that hitting GDP because they don't occur in big cities. Floods: same thing. 
4) 1% Major external issue, like bombing or other factor. Finally: what if Q3 is negative. We still need Q4 to be negative. -2%: I think if the administration fears recession they will pump fiscal stimulus into the economy.

Now this is a topic I really know something about. I've had to write reports on this a few months ago.  First, if 2 quarters of negative growth rate occur, that is basically considered a recession. This is an important distinction because there is some FED oversight reports about recessions.  So lets dig into this question from several angles:
- 10 year vs 3mo Yield Curve
- Unemployment 
- Housing starts
- issue of time: must occur in 2019 therefore Q2-Q3 or Q3-Q4 to qualify as a YES First: The 10yr-3mo Yield curve inverted, this has always indicated a recession is coming within 18 months. But bear in mind, we need 2 quarters to occur inside of 2019.
Second- Unemployment always is lowest just before a recession starts. Think about that a moment.  In our current case, unemployment curve has bottomed out and is starting to rise.
Third - Housing starts have peaked a few months ago All those factors paint a narrative that a recession is coming.  I've discussed this at length with an economist many nights on my back patio. We know it is coming, just not sure when.   The last function of the question is TIME.  That is the part that will get most of you in trouble. To have a YES this recession has to hurry up and happen fast.  Fortunately you don't have to rely upon your own analysis for timing. The Fed has an office in NY that does recession forecasting. Their output is here:  Fed US economy snapshot for April - https://www.newyorkfed.org/medialibrary/media/research/snapshot/snapshot_april2019.pdf?la=en
Fed's Recession Estimate (its 27% by March 2020)   - https://www.newyorkfed.org/research/capital_markets/ycfaq.html  (make sure you look at the pdf) ++++++++++++++++++++++ UPDATE ++++++++++++++++++

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-bonds-yieldcurve-analysis/onset-of-recession-may-take-longer-than-expected-after-yield-curve-inverts-idUSKBN1O90F5 DECEMBER 9, 2018 / 4 MONTHS AGO " . . .  The onset of a U.S. recession could take longer than usually thought after key points of the Treasury yield curve invert, as a surge in U.S. short-dated debt issuance has altered the dynamics of the Treasury market and other indicators show an economic downturn is farther off. As the Trump administration ramps up debt sales to cover a budget deficit projected to hit $1 trillion next year, it has crowded the front of the yield curve with far more new bonds than the back end. Banks, meanwhile, have shown a preference for mortgage-backed bonds over Treasuries since the financial crisis, a shift that has elevated the significance of moves in the yield curve of those bonds. These structural changes in supply and demand have some analysts thinking that means a longer lag until recession begins following any inversion of yields on two- and 10-year Treasuries, which has historically taken 18 months to two years. Some analysts and economists say that other yield curves may be better predictors of an impending economic downturn, and those are further away from flashing a warning signal than the two-year, 10-year Treasury spread.
. . . 
Analysts say that central banks’ quantitative easing programs since the financial crisis of 2007-2009 have distorted the yield curve, meaning that an inversion of two-year and 10-year notes, if it occurs, should not be read that a recession is necessarily near. “The current curve is massively distorted by QE and also the effects of the unwind,” said Thomas Simons, a money market economist at Jefferies in New York. The U.S. Treasury Department has increased supply of two-year notes by $82 billion since February, far exceeding $22 billion in 10-year notes it issued over the same time frame. “That’s a very significant amount of supply that’s been dumped into the front-end that hasn’t been equally distributed into the long-end,” said Simons. This has helped send yields on shorter-dated debt relatively higher, and compressed the spread between two-year and 10-year notes. Demand for Treasuries since the crisis has also changed, with banks increasingly turning to debt guaranteed by mortgage giants Fannie Mae (FNMA.PK) and Freddie Mac (FMCC.PK) as an alternative. “Given that banks are using it less than Fannie and Freddie, the importance of the Treasury curve has really diminished in the last nine-and-a-half years,” said Brian Reynolds, an analyst at Canaccord Genuity. Fannie and Freddie bonds offer a higher yield pickup than Treasuries, and their bailout by the U.S. government in 2008 gave them a government guarantee. U.S. banks have increased their holdings of mortgage-backed debt guaranteed by Fannie, Freddie and other government agencies to $2.23 trillion, from $1.16 trillion at the end of 2008, while Treasury holdings have increased to $503 billion from $56 billion during the same period, according to data by the Federal Reserve. The gap between two-year and 10-year Fannie and Freddie yields is currently around 24 basis points and 44 basis points, respectively, making any future inversion likely to come later than that of the Treasury curve. An economic paper by the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco in August, meanwhile, found that while the two-year, 10-year curve is typically the focus of financial commentators, the inversion between three-month bills and 10-year notes has better accuracy as a predictor of a recession 12 months into the future. That spread is also currently around 50 basis points, indicating that an inversion would occur later than that of the most commonly cited two-year, 10-year spread. “It could be many months before we see that point of the curve invert,” said Charlie Ripley, senior investment strategist at Allianz Investment Management.

Karen Brettell NEW YORK (Reuters) - Parts of the U.S. Treasury yield curve have begun moving in opposing directions, but closer scrutiny shows each section is signaling the same warning that the era of expanding economic growth and interest rate hikes is nearing an end. Analysts say Europe’s yield curve is also signaling economic weakness even as it holds at much steeper levels than the United States, reinforcing the notion that risks of a slowdown on both sides of the Atlantic are growing. The Federal Reserve’s sudden pivot toward a dovish stance on future rate increases in March stunned the market and prompted a rapid repricing of Treasuries that in less than a week led to an inversion of the 3-month and 10-year Treasury curve. The inversion, where 3-month bills return at a higher rate than the longer-dated notes, is an anomaly that in the past has preceded economic downturns by around one to two years. While that section of the curve has since moved back into positive territory, other shorter-dated parts of the curve remain inverted. Longer-dated parts of the yield curve have since steepened, which is also consistent with the end of the economic cycle that precedes interest rate cuts and a recession.

There's a lot of chatter about the 3mos/10yr curve recently inverting, but there's some nuance to that. First, as @cafebedouin and others have pointed out, this has generally been a long lead indicator.  I think the average lead time between previous inversions and recessions is on the order of a year.  So even if this inversion foretells a recession, based on historic patterns it's still a way off. Second, this inversion was just a blip.  Five days.  I'm pretty sure this has happened before without a follow-on recession. Third, if you read various discussions about the inversion, there are some things that make it a bit different from previous inversions.  I'm not enough of a bond expert to explain it in depth, but a significant portion of this inversion seems to be related to mortgage refinancing (as opposed to a flight to safety).  And one potential side effect of all the refinancing is more consumer money in the everyday economy. Within that context, I think the economy still has some wind in its sails, and even though it might be slowing down there's nothing I see that's screaming "Recession" in the next two quarters. And as a final note, even though I think any President gets somewhat exaggerated blame and credit for the economy on their watch, this particular President seems to be more acutely sensitive to it.  I believe he's promised 3% growth, and despite the fact that most credible analysts think that's out of reach, I think that he will do anything imaginable keep it going.  He might eventually run out of options, but I think there are things he can -- and might -- do in the next few quarters to keep a positive GDP growth.

A Weak First Quarter in 2019 for U.S. GDP; Second-Quarter Rebound Ahead March 8, 2019 The federal government shutdown in January will drag down reported first-quarter 2019 GDP growth, but the slowdown will be temporary. Second-quarter growth should rebound strongly, and growth should average at least 2.5% for the entire year. Growth was a decent 2.6% in the fourth quarter of 2018, following strong growth in the second and third quarters. Consumer spending grew 2.8% in the fourth quarter and will likely grow about the same in 2019. Income growth should still be strong because of low unemployment and lots of folks working. Government spending and housing construction will contribute modestly to growth, and businesses are adding to inventories. However, business investment is slowing markedly because of the uncertain outlook. Trade is likely to detract from growth, as slowing growth in overseas economies hurts exports. The added uncertainty of the U.S.-China trade war could create knock-on effects that slow business investment plans, and the need to rejig supply chains will reduce productivity and increase costs. Source: Department of Commerce: GDP Data Payne, D. (2019). A Weak First Quarter in 2019 for U.S. GDP; Second-Quarter Rebound Ahead. Kiplinger. Economic Forecast. March 8, 2019. Retrieved from
https://www.kiplinger.com/article/business/T019-C000-S010-gdp-growth-rate-and-forecast.html

The Conference Board Economic Forecast for the U.S. Economy
March 13, 2019 Fading domestic headwinds will keep growth above trend New GDP data show that after growing at a nearly four percent pace during the middle of 2018, growth slowed in the final quarter of the year to 2.6 percent. Still this figure is well above the US economy’s long-term two-percent trend. During 2019, expect growth to slow further, as effects from fiscal stimulus measures wane, but to remain above its trend through the end of the year. Consumer spending is buoyed by a tight labor market which is driving more rapid wage gains. Businesses face a shrinking pool of available workers that could slow growth further during the year unless past investments have raised labor productivity, which recent data provide modest signals to support. A shift in Federal Reserve policy towards looser monetary policy should keep business confidence and investment sufficiently solid throughout 2019. Much depends on inflation though. If prices rise more rapidly than anticipated, the Federal Reserve may still raise interest rates later in 2019 to prevent the economy from overheating. This may become a greater risk if businesses pass rising labor costs onto their customers. From a global perspective, 2019 sets up as a more challenging year for business than 2018. Growth in the Euro Area and China is slowing which will constrain opportunities for exports. A more favorable domestic monetary policy environment can keep growth above two percent into 2020 but cannot release the US economy from limits imposed by slow demographic growth. More promising is a rise in productivity growth during 2018. Spending on software and research and development accelerated rapidly last year and seems to have helped fuel productivity growth. Should this trend continue in 2019, businesses will have a chance to deploy new technologies and increase the efficiency of their workers. This represents the clearest path for keeping revenue and profit growth robust in 2019 and beyond. 
The Conference Board Website. (2019). The Conference Board Economic Forecast for the U.S. Economy. U. S. Economic Forecast. The Conference Board. United States. March 13, 2019. Retrieved from

Sticking to 9%. Aside from the FOMC's January minutes, last week did not contain too much forecasting information.  This week, on the other hand, is chocked full of it.  So I was inclined to just sit it out to see what shakes, but I came across a podcast that had an interesting view that I wanted to share. The podcast is an interview with a guy named Adam Robinson.  He seems to be a polymath of sorts, with a very interesting string of accomplishments.  I won't bore you with them because he's easy enough to Google.  Also, you can listen to Part I: https://fs.blog/adam-robinson-pt1/ Anyway, Adam has a hierarchy for who in the financial world really has their finger of the pulse. At the top of the heap are the metals traders, followed by the bond traders.  At the very bottom are the central bankers, and just above them economists in general.  In the middle are equities traders and currency traders. In the world of metal trading, he swore that the ratio of price-for-copper over price-for-gold has historically been the most accurate predictor of what's ahead for the economy.  When things are good, there is a demand for copper (electronics, etc.), and the price goes up.  On the other hand, when things are good the price of gold goes down.  So a very high ratio is a signal that things are good, and a climbing ratio is a signal that things are getting better.  At least as metal traders see it. On the other hand, when things are slowing down the demand for copper goes down, and the demand for gold does up.  So the ratio starts dropping. You can see some historical ratios here: http://www.infomine.com/investment/price-ratios/copper-gold/ As you can see, the ratio for the past year or so has been relatively flat.  It hit bottom in the summer 2016...shot back up...and has been dancing around 0.15 - 0.16 ever since.   To the extent that this is, indeed, a good signal, I take it to mean that the metal traders view things as relatively stable.   But is it a good signal? Given how strongly Adam Robinson gushed about it in the podcast, I would have expected there to be tons of web sites and blogs referring to it.   There are some, for sure, but it doesn't appear to carry the same weight was bond ratios. To me, though, it is another little signal.  And as far as that goes, it's seems to be signalling either stability or uncertainty.  But there does not seem to be an indication that metal traders think we are in for dire times in the immediate future.  At least not at this point.

Sticking to 9% Last week was a busy and noisy week in terms of indicators, indices, and opinions.  I was wondering how I was going to capture it all in an informative yet readable post.  Then the Wall Street Journal came to the rescue on Saturday with a story: “Smattering of Contradictory Data Confounds Economists.”   The story opened with, “Economic data are usually noisy, but this week included an onslaught of negative and often contradictory signals that made even seasoned economists scratch their heads.” For example, it went on to say, “A Federal Reserve report on Friday showed U.S. industrial production dropped sharply in January , even though other data have suggested the manufacturing sector remains strong. Then the University of Michigan reported a February rebound in consumer sentiment, a day after the Commerce Department said consumer spending sank during the holiday shopping season. And so on. So I won’t spend a lot of time fleshing out what the WSJ has summarized so well.  The point is, the data were confusing this past week.  I still think the chances of two consecutive quarters of negative real GDP growth are slim for two reasons: First, the jobs numbers and the jobs opening numbers — both of which have been published recently — are strong.  Very strong.  And consumer spending is the foundation of GDP growth. Second, I was looking at the chart that @pietrokc posted on 15 Feb.   https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/gdp-growth GDP growth in recent quarters has been relatively strong.  And if you look at the longer history, you can see that GDP often falls for 2 - 3 quarters without going into recession territory.   Does that mean it won’t happen this time? Gottfried Liebniz once said, “Nature has established patterns originating in the return of events, but only for the most part.”  That’s one of my North Star decision tools; I try not to put too much stock into past patterns like this. But that doesn’t mean I ignore them, either.  I do think it’s worth noting that GDP growth goes up and down all the time.  And just because we have some weaknesses right now does not mean that the long-awaited recession is finally upon us.

Consensus at 20% seems too high. I don't know much about GDP or whatever. But it seems to me there ought to be two regimes to this. (1) In a big recession, everything goes down for a long time. So negative GDP growth in consecutive quarters is heavily correlated. This happened in 2008-2009, when we had 4 consecutive quarters of negative growth.
(2) Outside of a big recession, negative growth in consecutive quarters should be ANTI-correlated. If GDP goes down one quarter, well, now it's lower, so it ought to be easier to go higher. Huge recessions like 2008-2009 are pretty rare. And we'd need one to hit by 2019Q3 at the latest. Counting from [1] I kinda see 5 big ones in the last 60 years, giving ~8.3% chance per year. Make it 6% because of the time constraint. Without a huge recession we are in (2) territory. I give it 1% chance here due to the rarity of gdp decline, and the anti-correlation effect. [1] https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/gdp-growth

Lowering to 9% based on slight preponderance of not-bad news. I. Overview The slight preponderance of not-bad news starts with the IMF lowering its global economic growth forecast for this year from 3.7 per cent to 3.5 per cent.  I consider that good news because 3.5 percent growth is still fairly strong (and definitely positive).   II. Bond Market   To the extent that the bond market knows things before the stock market, and the yield curve is its way of transmitting that knowledge, the signals appear to be mixed. I was under the impression the 2-yr/10-yr curve was the bellweather, and that seems stable right now.  It started last week with a 0.18 spread, and ended with a 0.18 spread (possible good news). On the other hand, some time ago someone posted a link to a NY Fed site that forecasts the probability of a recession, and it seems the NY Fed uses the 3-mo/10-yr.  And that yield curve narrowed significantly last week, dropping from 0.30 to 0.20 last week (possible bad news). III. Fed The Fed — writ large — didn’t say much last week that pertains to this forecast, but the NY Fed upped the probability of a recession during the next 12 months from 21% to 23.6% based on the 3-mo/10-yr spread.  That's not great news, but I don't think it's bad news, either. IV. GDP A. Consumer Spending   Unit vehicle sales for January were at a 16.6 million annualized rate vs 17.5 million in December. This is a slow start to first-quarter as far as consumer spending goes, but still pretty solid. B. Business Investments There was an article in the WSJ last Tuesday extolling the importance of Purchasing Managers Indexes (PMI) as a leading indicator.  Not coincidentally, that same day  Econoday reported that the Institute for Supply Management’s (ISM) non-manufacturing sample showed good growth for January at 56.7. There was a lot of chatter on Econoday about various nuances if you parse the data, but the bottom line was “overall rates of growth for both this sample and the services PMI sample remain healthy and favorable and consistent with solid and sustainable GDP growth.” C. Government Spending Nothing of note on the government spending front. D. Net Exports These reports tend to lag pretty much in general, and the government slowdown didn’t help.  But it seems there was a pullback in imports late last year that decreased the trade deficit a bit. The conventional wisdom seems to be that even though there is a general weakness in exports, fourth quarter GDP estimates may rise. V. Misc Earnings. The past two weeks have been earnings season, and apparently this is pretty closely watched.  Goldman Sachs reported, “47% of firms have beaten consensus EPS estimates by at least 1 standard deviation [and while] the percentage of firms beating on the bottom line has moderated from 56% in 3Q, [it] remains in line with the long-term average…EPS grew by 14% during 4Q, up from the 12% consensus forecast prior to the season [and] as a result of low investor expectations, firms beating on the bottom line have outperformed S&P 500 by 247 bp on the day after reporting earnings, the highest magnitude of outperformance since 3Q 2009.” Although the first-order effects would seem to be tied to the stock market, if companies are doing well it can probably also be inferred they will carry on with business investments. VI. Conclusion   It would not surprise me to much if the last quarter of 2019 turns out to have negative real GDP, but I think two consecutive quarters is unlikely.

I’m sticking to 11% based on a few positive indicators last week as well as a few negative indicators. I. The Bond Market The 2s10s yield curve widened a bit last week.  It opened the week with a 0.16 spread, and closed the week with a 0.18 spread.  I did a few spot checks on other yield curves, and they widened, also.  To the extent that this is a long leading indicator of a recession, it appears the bond market does not think one is in the cards soon.   II. The Fed The Fed met and decided to leave the overnight lending rate unchanged, and there has been no end to various narratives around the meaning of this.  On the negative side, one can say the Fed sees dark clouds on the economic horizon (e.g., a possible economic slowing, or recession).  OK, but still, the Fed is doing what it’s supposed to do in those cases: it’s easing up on interest rate hikes to bolster the economy. And by easing up on interest rate hikes, it will make consumer spending and business investments (the two biggest components of GDP) easier, because personal and business borrowing will not get more expensive.   III. GDP Components A. Consumer Spending  1. Employment.  The big news here is the Employment Situation report, which came out on Friday.  304,000 net jobs added in January, which beat the consensus estimate of 158,000 by quite a bit.  As consumer spending is a huge part of GDP, this bodes well (at least for now).  2. Housing.  On the up side, New home sales jumped 16.9 percent in November to a 657,000 annualized rate, and construction spending rose a decent  0.8 percent in November .  On the down side, pending home sales on the resale market dropped 6.4 percent in December, which was the lowest in more than three years.   3. Consumer Sentiment.  This is down 7.1% from December.  Not so good, although it arguably just suffered from the government shutdown. 4. Personal Income and Outlays. This report has been delayed but personal income is seen rising 0.4 percent (very good) in December. At the same time, consumer spending is expected to increase 0.3 percent (moderate).  Six-month buying plans show a small uptick for autos, a large downtick for major appliances. B. Business Investments Both the PMI manufacturing index and the ISM manufacturing index were very good.  PMI came in at 54.9, which is just a bit over the previous 53.8.  ISM came in at 56.6, which is solidly over the previous 54.3.  Both of these reports are saying the same thing: there was solid growth in January. This is consistent with a Wall Street Journal article of 28 January in which railroad executives reported that customers are planning to ship more goods, and are also moving ahead with long-term capital projects, to include expanding facilities. C. Government Spending The government re-opened (at least temporarily) and the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) estimates that the government shutdown will nick 0.4% off the GDP, making it 2.1% growth.  Goldman Sachs estimates the same 0.4% nick, but believes the final figure for GDP growth will be 1.9%. D. Net Exports The International Trade in Goods Report was delayed, so it’s hard to say anything about net exports.  But this only accounted for -5% of the GDP in 2017, so it’s not really one of the long poles in the tent. IV. Conclusion. Again, there are a lot of mixed signals just now.  Some describe last week’s data as indicating a Goldilocks economy.  Others see nothing but doom and gloom.  I am strongly inclined to think we’ll make it though 2019 with no more than one negative quarter mainly because the 800 pound gorilla of the GDP (consumer spending) and its younger brother (business investments) are so positive just now.

In the history after 1950 the US economy expirienced 11 recession periods according to NBRE definition, but only in 9 of them real GDP fell in two consecutive quarters (and never GDP fell in two consecutive qurters without a NBER recession). 9 cases in approx. 7 decades is a quite low probability. However, the odds that 2019 will become a recession year are clearly higher as the recovery is already mature (the upswing started in Q3 2009), many indicators are already heading south and the trade war is a burden fore GDP growth, too. However, there is little evidence that a recession will start already in Q1. The odds are higher for a start in Q2, but still not really high and again somewhat higher for Q3. This means, that the odds for two consecutive negative quarters in 2019 decrease: If the recession just starts in Q4, it ois obvious that two negative quarters in 2019 are impossible. But even if it starts in Q2 or Q3: In two out of the nine periods the 4th and 5th recession quarter were the two first with two consequtive quarters of negrtive real GDP growth and only in seven of this cases that happend right from the start or in the second and third quarter of the recession. So, as long as economic data remain more or less robust, I guess the chances of two negative quarters fairly small.

The book is Masters of Nothing: How the Crash Will Happen Again Unless We Understand Human Nature by Matthew Hancock and Nadhim Zahawi (published in 2011 in the UK by Biteback Publishing and available on pre-order in the US). In 2004, the book explains, the deputy governor of the Bank of England (the UK central bank), Sir Andrew Large, gave a powerful and eloquent warning about the coming crash at the London School of Economics. The speech was published on the bank’s website but it received no notice. There were no seminars called. No research was commissioned. No newspaper referred to the speech. Sir Andrew continued to make similar speeches and argue for another two years that the system was unsustainable. His speeches infuriated the then Chancellor, Gordon Brown, because they warned of the dangers of excessive borrowing. In January 2006, Sir Andrew gave up: he quietly retired before his term was up. In 2005, the chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, Raghuram Rajan, made a speech at Jackson Hole Wyoming in front of the world’s most important bankers and financiers, including Alan Greenspan and Larry Summers. He argued that technical change, institutional moves and deregulation had made the financial system unstable. Incentives to make short-term profits were encouraging the taking of risks, which if they materialized would have catastrophic consequences. The speech did not go down well. Among the first to speak was Larry Summers who said the speech was “largely misguided”.

I am backing off a bit to 11% for now. Going back to my initial forecast using the 2s10s yield curve, the current spread is 0.16, which is where it began this year.  It went up just a bit to the 0.18/0.19 range a little more than a week ago, and now it’s back where it started the year.  At this point I see nothing to get excited about. Within that context, there is a saying, “Bull markets do not die of old age, the Fed murders them.” Although I’m not confusing a bear market with a recession, the fact is that Fed rate hikes affect the economy as well as the stock market.  And from everything I’ve read, the Fed seems to have backed off a bit on both the commitment to rate hikes and the QT.  Although employment is humming (see below), inflation remains low for now.   So from a monetary policy point of view, it appears the rest of 2019 will support continued growth. Moving on… Looking at the components of GDP is a bit tricky since the government shutdown apparently precluded some data from being collected/reported, but there are some data points.  1. Consumer spending This is about 70% of GDP, and it’s looking good. Jobless Claims: Although there was a rise in claims by (apparently) furloughed workers, initial jobless claims fell 13,000 and were at 199,000 last week. This is the lowest rate in about 50 years. Home Sales: It’s true, home sales fell 6.4% in December, but mortgage rates were still coming down off November highs.   Mortgage rates peaked in November and have since declined about 40 basis points to roughly 4.75 percent for 30-year fixed mortgages.  Bank of America reported on 22 January that sentiment among home builders rose for the first time in three months.  The feeling is that there is a pent-up demand, and now that mortgage rates have declined the spring selling season will see the market rebound somewhat. Consumer spending is the 800 pound gorilla in the GDP, and it’s looking pretty lively.  It would take a lot of downside in the other factors to counteract this. 2. Business Investments This is about 18% of GDP. On the one hand, Peterson Institute for International Economics (PIIE) reported on 24 January that foreign direct investments (FDI) have fallen significantly, and they made passing reference to domestic investments falling, also.    On the other hand, Market Watch reported on 22 January about a survey of Federal Reserve Senior Load officers, and said “credit conditions for both commercial and industrial firms remain accommodative, with the banking community willing to extend funding to corporate borrowers. While one could argue that easy credit has led to a record level of debt for non-financial corporations and could eventually pose a problem were the economy to slow noticeably, for now it portends future economic growth with credit conditions for commercial and industrial firms leading real GDP by about nine months. Based on where credit conditions are right now, we should see decent economic growth well into 2019.” So I’m around neutral in my thoughts about business investments. 3. Government Spending This is about 17% of GDP. Well, the shutdown is over for now.   In a rational world one might think that the President and his allies in the Congress would have learned a thing or two from this little standoff and would be hugely reluctant to try a repeat.  On the other hand…it’s not exactly a rational world just now, is it? That said, with 2020 right around the corner, and everyone realizing how much of a negative economic impact these shutdown sort of things have, I’m inclined to believe that self-interest will prevail and the President will do everything possible to keep spending up. So as with business investments, I am more or less neutral here. 4. Net Exports This is about 5% of GDP (-5%, actually) On the one hand, the global trade front is looking dour.  China is having problems…Europe is having problems…and the IMF is making noise about a global economic slowdown.   But again, it only accounted for 5% of the GDP the last time those numbers were available, and a global economic slowdown would have to be pretty serious to make a significant dent in US GDP. Summary.  So all in all I am feeling pretty sanguine about it this week.  It is definitely easy to imagine a slowdown of US GDP, but two quarters of real negative growth seems a bit of a stretch right now. And on a final note, this will be an interesting week.  The GDP report is due out Wednesday morning, and an FOMC meeting report on is due out Wednesday afternoon (not to mention a few other key indicators later in the week, as well as earnings reports from some of the big guns).

If the base rate of a recession in the US is roughly once every 8-9 years, then the economy should be due for a contraction.  However, conditioning the probability of a recession based on financial and economic data shows that the likelihood of recession - while elevated - is still relatively low.  The spread between the 3M T-bill and 10yr US Treasury yields is still positive and the near-term forward spread, as researched by FRBSF, is positive as well.  Overall Financial Conditions as measured by the Chicago Fed are still historically loose and Non-financial Leverage is low relatively speaking.  On a more subjective note, the tax cuts and fiscal stimulus are likely to carry over into at least the first half of 2019 and contribute less in the second half of the year.  By the definition of this question - two consecutive quarters of negative real GDP growth - and given that the most reliable yield curve spreads are still positive, I give the chance of recession to be much less than baseline and unlikely in 2019.

**updates:  As a non-economist, how do I make this percentage estimate quantitative? Here's my shot: 
1) History suggests that when recessions do occur they are not widely anticipated by consensus GDP forecasts and only a small fraction (like less than 10%) of economists predict a recession in the October of the prior year, which is only 3x more than predict recessions when they don't occur! By April people have figured it out, on average. The general pattern is that GDP forecasts start out at around the long-term trend (call it ~3%) and decline to around zero by April. In October they were 2.7-3.0%. So, that means that if we are on track for a recession that consensus forecasts should be around 1.3-1.4% now. They're not, there around 2.4-2.5%. So that means consensus is dropping around 0.1% per month, which isn't on track for a recession, but still within say 1 sigma of the trend. So based on that data I would say we're looking at <30% of recession in 2019. 
2) We have not yet seen a full inversion of the yield curve, which has preceded every recent recession with a lead of roughly 12-18 months. It's possible that we will see a recession without a yield curve inversion. Call that 10%. It's possible that we will see a yield curve inversion and then have a short lag to recession which in this case would need to be < 6 months. i'll call that another 10%. => 20% total. 
3) LEI peaked in September, so the beginning of the 9-18 month window from then would be June 2019. (NOTE: This was hardly reported in the press. The revision to the October LEi was -0.4!). This seems like the strongest indication of recession. If that was indeed the peak, then it seems to indicate a probability of something like 40%. However, there is also a chance that LEI continues moving upward and sets a new peak and in that case we're unlikely to have 2 negative quarters in 2019. Call that probability 50%. => 20%. Ok, so based on all that I would average those three values for lack of a better methodology. => average(30%, 20%, 20%) = 23% Based on earlier calculations => average (30%, 20%, 20%) = 23% Best guess of GDP as things stand => ~1.5 consensus forecast in April. All that said, I think there are macro factors that aren't included in that (except indirectly through the yield curve and stock market component of the LEI). 
**-- Odds of messy Brexit have increased. could have a -4 to 5% impact on UK GDP. What would that do for US GDP? Some thoughts: 1) will hurt out trade with the UK. -0.1%, tops; 2) will increase the dollar and hurt our trade with other countries => possibly significant. 
-- China trade. First order impacts are probably reflected well in stock prices. Who knows about 2nd order. ?? 
**-- Shutdown longer and pain deepening. Already has cost the economy something like ~-0.1 - 0.3%. My best guess from what I've read is 0.1% of GDP per week, currently at 0.4% of GDP. My sense is that the damage is accelerating especially in terms of impact on consumer and business confidence. So my best guess is 0.7% +/-1.5%. So roughly 45% chance of recession. I'll take the average: 23% and 45% => 34%

Two consecutive negative quarterly GPD growth rates is an indicator of a recession.  There have been 7 episodes of two consecutive negative quarterly growth rates since 1950 [1].  What is the likelihood that this is coming in 2019? Recent volatility and corrections in the stock market leads to speculations that a recession is coming.  While many people believe that a stock market correction precedes a recession (as defined by the two consecutive negative growth rates), it is not necessarily the case.  For example, the dot com bust in 2001 was not associated with 2 consecutive negative growth rates [1].  In other words, a bear market does not necessarily result in two consecutive negative growth rates. The trade war intensified from mid-year 2018 and it could significantly affect the GDO growth.  However, the growth rates in the last two quarters in 2018 are 4.2% and 3.5%, respectively [1].   The larger number (4.2%) is probably affected by the stockpiling of goods prior to the trade war.  However, the second number (3.5%) probably reflects the actual effects of the trade war.  Some people argue that without the trade war, the GDP growth would have been much higher in that quarter [2].  If this argument holds, it means that the underlying growth rate in the U.S. is high enough to counterbalance the negative effect of the trade war.  China and the U.S. are negotiating on the trade issues.  While a positive outcome is not guaranteed, both countries realize that it is in its own interest to arrive in a settlement.  It is a question of coming up with a compromise to let Trump declared a “win” and China to “save face” (declaring that it did not succumb to the U.S.).  The current negotiation deadline is the end of March.  While I am not convinced that the negotiations will be completed by that time, I don’t see that they will drag on to result in a recession, or two quarterly negative growth. [2]  https://www.businessinsider.com/gdp-trump-tariff-trade-war-us-china-2018-10

Raising my forecast to 13%.  I still think the probability of two consecutive quarters of negative real GDP growth is low, but I think it’s a little more likely than my initial forecast indicated. It seems GDP is computed from the following four components (the percentages are from 2017, the last year for which I was able to get solid data): 	1. Personal consumption ( 70% )
	2. Business Investments  (18% )
	3. Government spending  (17% )
	4. Net exports ( -5% ) Taking each one separately: 1. Personal consumption On the one hand, employment figures have been very good.  There definitely appears to be more money there from consumers to spend. One the other hand, the University of Michigan Consumer Sentiment Index shows that consumer confidence fell from 98.3 to 90.7.  Apparently economists had forecast the index to be 96.  So that’s a little bit of bad news.   There has also been some chatter about an “automobile recession.”   From what I can tell, this is essentially about the shift from sedans to SUVs, and a Bloomberg article from 13 January opines that this could result in about 20,000 job losses as plants close. So although I am generally positive about this sector of the GDP, I think there are a few potential clouds in the horizon. 2. Business Investments This is an area where the Fed can make a difference.  Business investments consist of fixed investments and changes in inventory.  Those fixed investments often come from borrowing, which is sensitive to interest rates. The Fed has indicated it is going to be flexible with future rate hikes.  Since inflation does not appear to be an issue, I suspect the Fed will go easy on rate hikes this year and try to maintain some forward momentum with respect to business investments. In any case, I have not found any indications that businesses are rethinking their investment plans to the point that it might have a serious impact on GDP, while at the same time it seems the Fed is "listening." 3. Government spending Although this has everyone’s attention right now, and it is having an effect of GDP, this is also an area where Donald Trump can have a lot of impact.  His advisors are apparently acknowledging that the shutdown is having a bigger negative economic effect than they had anticipated, and — coincidence? — Trump is now at least trying to appear to be making concessions in his dealings with the Democrats in Congress.   No matter what, at this point I don’t think he’s going to seriously risk a recession over The Wall when 2020 is right around the corner. 4. Net exports   This is the toughest one of the four for me to formulate a coherent opinion about.  Notice that in 2017 net exports contributed -5% to the GDP.  I’m not certain, but I believe this was from trade deficits. Our biggest trading partners are: 		Canada: US$282.5 billion (18.3% of total US exports)
		Mexico: $243 billion (15.7%)
		China: $130.4 billion (8.4%)
		Japan: $67.7 billion (4.4%)
		United Kingdom: $56.3 billion (3.6%)
		Germany: $53.5 billion (3.5%)
		South Korea: $48.3 billion (3.1%) Of those, we’re having issues with Canada and Mexico in the form of whatever is replacing (or has replaced) NAFTA; we’re having issues with China in the form of a simmering trade war (and China itself is having some internal economic issues); the UK seems to be possibly on the verge of a hard Brexit; and Germany is having some internal economic problems. How might these issues affect trade deficits this year, and consequently on the GDP?  Again, it’s hard for me to gauge that, and until I can better get my head around this I’ll stay neutral on it. So in general, I think the possibility of two consecutive quarters of negative real GDP growth is higher than it was, but I still think it’s relatively low.   And coincidentally, Goldman Sachs issued a report sometime this past week that — from what I can tell — arrives at the same conclusion.  I don’t have access to the report, but I’ve read some analyses of it.  Although GS approaches  the possibility of a recession this year from an entirely different direction than the one I just laid out, their conclusion seems to be about the same.

I am making an initial forecast of 3%. A US government bond yield curve inversion is generally considered a long leading indicator of a recession.  To me this is kind of a tricky proposition for several reasons. First, which yield curve?  If you survey all the web sites and such, you can find people using the 1 mo/30yr at one end, and people using the 2yr/5yr at the other end.  I am going to focus on the 2yr/10yr for two reasons: (1) a plurality of people and organizations seem to use it, and (2) the CFA question here last fall involved the 2yr/10yr, which leads me to infer it has some special significance. Second, the sample size.  As far as I can tell, there have only been 11 recessions since WWII.  There were apparently several recessions in the ‘50s and ‘60s that were not preceded by a yield curve inversion, and I have read that the curve inverted twice in the late-60s without follow-on recessions [1]. The real correlation appears to have started in the late-70s.  Since 1978 there have been five recessions, and each has been preceded by a yield curve inversion.  That’s an incredibly small sample size from which to be making inferences.  Nonetheless, this seems to be something of a gold standard, so I am going to start there. Third, the data.  I cannot find a single authoritative source of all the data I would like: both the dates of 2yr/10yr yield curve inversions, and the dates that recessions start.  One would think the Fed would have it, but I could not find it.  So I’ve had to cobble together a data set from different sources, and I’m not 100% sure of its accuracy. That said, if I did gather and interpret the numbers correctly, since 1978 the times (in months) between a 2yr/10yr yield curve inversion and the beginning of a recession have been 17, 10, 19, 11, and 24.  The average lead time, then, has been 16.2 months, with the minimum lead time being 10 months.  (Note: that fourth lead time — 11 months — is probably subject to debate, but I am going to be conservative and use it.) The current 2yr/10yr spread is 0.16.  Assuming something really dastardly happens and it goes down below zero over, say, the next several weeks, on average that would presage the beginning of a recession by 16.2 months.  This would be Q2 2020.  Even if we went with the minimum historic lead time, this would be Q4 2019. So I am inclined to think the probability of two consecutive quarters of negative GDP are pretty close to nil.  This is in line with several other forecasts that use yield curve inversion models.  That said, there are a few reasons why I am not saying 0% probability. The GDP is generally thought of as having four components: personal consumption expenditures, investments, net exports, and government expenditures. In looking at those four and the current administration, it’s not hard to imagine the GDP taking some sort of hit due to decreased government expenditures and decreased net exports. Although the current government shutdown only affects a portion of the government, there is a debt ceiling issue coming up on 01 March.  Who knows what’s going to happen at that point. On top of that, both Europe and China (trading partners) are experiencing economic headwinds, and Trump seems bent on having trade wars with some of our biggest trading partners.  It’s possible exports could take a hit. And finally, there is one factor that makes this situation a bit different from previous situations, and that is the years of quantitative easing and the current quantitative tightening.  New territory here...maybe this is the recession that is not preceded by a yield curve inversion. So I am adding a few points to my forecast to account for these factors. [1] “The Inverted Yield Curve: Historical Perspectives and Implications on Cash Portfolios”, Capital Advisors Group, 1 March 2006

As a non-economist, how do I make this percentage estimate quantitative?  Here's my shot: 
1) History suggests that when recessions do occur they are not widely anticipated by consensus GDP forecasts and only a small fraction (like less than 10%) of economists predict a recession in the October of the prior year, which is only 3x more than predict recessions when they don't occur! By April people have figured it out, on average. The general pattern is that GDP forecasts start out at around the long-term trend (call it ~3%) and decline to around zero by April. In October they were 2.7-3.0%. So, that means that if we are on track for a recession that consensus forecasts should be around 1.3-1.4% now. They're not, there around 2.4-2.5%. So that means consensus is dropping around 0.1% per month, which isn't on track for a recession, but still within say 1 sigma of the trend. So based on that data I would say we're looking at <30% of recession in 2019. 
2) We have not yet seen a full inversion of the yield curve, which has preceded every recent recession with a lead of roughly 12-18 months. It's possible that we will see a recession without a yield curve inversion. Call that 10%. It's possible that we will see a yield curve inversion and then have a short lag to recession which in this case would need to be < 6 months. i'll call that another 10%. => 20% total.
3) LEI peaked in September, so the beginning of the 9-18 month window from then would be June 2019. (NOTE: This was hardly reported in the press. The revision to the October LEi was -0.4!). This seems like the strongest indication of recession. If that was indeed the peak, then it seems to indicate a probability of something like 40%. However, there is also a chance that LEI continues moving upward and sets a new peak and in that case we're unlikely to have 2 negative quarters in 2019. Call that probability 50%. => 20%. Ok, so based on all that I would average those three values for lack of a better methodology. => average(30%, 20%, 20%) = 23% Best guess of GDP as things stand => ~1.5 consensus forecast in April. All that said, I think there are macro factors that aren't included in that (except indirectly through the yield curve and stock market component of the LEI). 
    -- messy Brexit could have a -4 to 5% impact on UK GDP. What would that do for US GDP? Some thoughts: 1) will hurt out trade with the UK. -0.1%, tops; 2) will increase the dollar and hurt our trade with other countries => possibly significant.
    -- China trade. First order impacts are probably reflected well in stock prices. Who knows about 2nd order. ??
    -- Shutdown. Already has cost the economy something like ~-0.1 - 0.3%. So my best guess is 0.8% +/-1.5%.  So roughly 40% chance of recession. I'll take the average: 23% and 40% => 32%

In my reading I've come across a few reasons that people give for predicting a recession / no recession soon - the most common are a) duration of the current business cycle and b) the yield curve / treasury spread. Below I use data to test these claims. I find that a) the duration of the current business cycle has no predictive power; and b) the treasury spread gives strong evidence that we are not going to see a recession soon. While the treasury spread doesn't rule out a recession soon, it does make me think it's less likely (hence I'm adjusting my forecast from 6% to 4%). (In future updates I'll address the trade war, low unemployment, and the stock market.)     • Duration of the current business cycle
        ◦ Business cycles aren’t cycles – they’re fluctuations. The fact that there’s been a long duration since the last period of negative growth doesn’t make it more likely that we’ll see negative growth soon. But don’t take my word for it – here’s the evidence.
        ◦ Open this link, which has 5 graphs I generated, and have it handy while you read this post (https://imgur.com/a/YC9l1BJ).
        ◦ For each quarter from 1947 – 2017, I calculated a) the duration of the business cycle up to this point and b) whether or not the next quarter is negative. [SEE GRAPH 1]. Notice how there is no strong pattern to whether or not a data point (= a quarter) appears on the bottom or the top. If longer business cycles were more likely to lead to negative growth next cycle, we would see data points crowded around the bottom-left and top-right. (Note: because the spreadsheet software lets points sit on top of each other, this does hide the duplicate data points – sorry! but it gets the idea across).
        ◦ I also generated a simple regression model and a generalized linear model to test whether the duration of the cycle affects the probability of next quarter being negative – none of my models showed a statistically significant effect (p = 0.2927 and 0.294 respectively, where p < 0.1 or p < 0.05 would give evidence of a trend; also, effect sizes were very small).
        ◦ I also made a graph of the length of business cycles (i.e. the # of quarters of positive growth in a row) [SEE GRAPH 2]. Compare to a roughly representative distribution of random numbers [SEE GRAPH 3]. The business cycle data is skewed compared to random numbers – we’re more likely to see shorter cycles. (To be clear, these graphs are simply an ordered list of business cycle lengths – on the y-axis is length, and the x-axis is meaningless.)
        ◦ But notice that there are loads of 1’s and 2’s – which is not meaningful for today, as we’re currently in the 18th consecutive quarter of growth. Removing 1’s and 2’s and repeating the above graphs gives the real data [SEE GRAPH 4] and the random numbers [SEE GRAPH 5]. They look much more similar. (Removing the 1’s from the linear models above made the models even weaker.)
        ◦ Combining all this data makes it very hard to believe that longer cycles make it more likely to see negative growth next quarter.     • Shape of the yield curve
        ◦ I’ve seen some claims that the slope of the yield curve / treasury spread is a strong predictor of recessions – these people claim that a negative slope means there’s a high probability of a recession.
        ◦ I downloaded historical data from here (https://www.newyorkfed.org/research/capital_markets/ycfaq.html)
        ◦ The same data appears on this PDF, which shows that negative treasury spreads tend to appear before recessions (https://www.newyorkfed.org/medialibrary/media/research/capital_markets/Prob_Rec.pdf)
        ◦ This dataset calculates the slope of the yield curve as 10 year bond rate minus 3 month bill rate (bond equivalent basis). Note that the data starts in 1959.
        ◦ First, I converted the monthly data to quarterly by producing averages for each three months.
        ◦ The periods of negative growth over 2+ quarters happen in: 1970; 1974; 1980; 1982; 1991; and 2008. The periods where the treasury spread was negative begin in: 1966; 1969; 1973; 1978; 1980; 1989; 2000; 2006. 
            ▪ That means, if we take the treasury spread as a prediction saying “there will be a recession in the next 1-2 years”, there are 6 out of 8 predictions that are correct, and 0 times when a recession was missed. How cool is that!
        ◦ I’m a little blown away by the agreement here – it looks like the treasury spread is a good predictor of recessions after all. But how strong is it for our purposes?
            ▪ Firstly, there’s a time lag – for the 6 periods of 2+ period negative growth above, after the spread falls below 0, there’s (on average) an 5.2-quarter lag until the onset of negative growth. So negative spread means that there’ll probably be a recession in a year and a bit.
            ▪ For 2018 Q3, the spread was 0.848. We don’t have data for Dec 2018, but the first two-thirds of 2018 Q4 had an average spread of 0.800. Indeed, the spread has been declining steadily since mid-2017.
            ▪ Let’s take the 0.8 threshold – how many times after a spread of 0.8, where we don’t just skip straight to negative spread, does a recession happen? In other words, if we find ourselves with a spread of 0.8 or less, is this a sign of an impeding recession?
                • 1959-60 (no recession); 1963-1967 (no recession); 1967-70 (recession); 1973-4 (recession); 1989-90 (recession, but later); 1995 (no recession); 1997-9 (no recession); 2000 (no recession); 2005-7 (recession, but later)
                • This means that periods that have spreads as low as we currently have are about as likely to have a recession as not have a recession – just under a 50% rate. But in none of these did the recession appear within 3 quarters. This matches what I found above, with a time lag between low yield and negative growth.
            ▪ So, every period of double negative growth since 1959 has been preceded by negative treasury spread. When we see negative treasury spread, we’re likely to have a recession within just over a year (historical minimum is 3 quarters).
            ▪ But there is no case since 1959 where there has been a recession without having seen positive treasury spread. So while it's possible our declining treasury spread is evidence that a recession is coming, the probability of seeing it in the next 3 quarters is quite low.

Edit: Also see my second comment, where I look at business cycles and treasury spread: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/811838 Since 1947 (i.e. over 286 quarters):
    1. Average rate of growth is 3.22%.
    2. 41 periods have experienced negative real GDP growth.
    3. In 10 instances has there been 2+ negative real GDP growth – 7 instances of double-period negative growth; 2 instances of triple-period; and 1 instance of quadruple-period.
    4. For these instances, for the quarter before the onset of negative growth, the average rate was 2.2%. The rate of Q3 2018 was 3.4% - only in 2 out of 10 instances has this occurred. (Will need to update once I see Q4 2018 rate.)
    5. If you look at four quarters before the onset of negative growth, the average rate was 2.83%. Today, the rate of the last four quarters is 3.02% - only in 3 out of 10 of the aforementioned instances has the rate been this high.
    6. The correlation between the growth rate for one quarter and the growth rate for the next quarter is 36%. This is better than random, but only moderately so. (There is no apparent correlation for data since 2009, which may be an artifact of small sample size.)
    7. Although growth has declined over time, there is no evidence of a change in frequency of instances of negative growth over time. Calculating the probability
    • 41 periods over 286 quarters makes 14.34%. So probability of a period having negative growth is 14.34%, and positive growth 85.66%.
      You can do a simple possibility tree with pen and paper. Of the 28 possible options for Q1 – Q4 each being positive or negative, only 8 include 2+ negative periods in a row. Numbers in brackets indicate all four probabilities multiplied.
        ◦ Q1 negative, Q2 negative, Q3 negative, Q4 negative (0.04223%)
        ◦ Q1 negative, Q2 negative, Q3 negative, Q4 positive (0.2524%)
        ◦ Q1 negative, Q2 negative, Q3 positive, Q4 negative (0.2524%)
        ◦ Q1 negative, Q2 negative, Q3 positive, Q4 positive (1.508%)
        ◦ Q1 negative, Q2 positive, Q3 negative, Q4 negative (0.2524%)
        ◦ Q1 positive, Q2 positive, Q3 negative, Q4 negative (1.508%)
        ◦ Q1 positive, Q2 negative, Q3 negative, Q4 negative (0.2524%)
        ◦ Q1 positive, Q2 negative, Q3 negative, Q4 positive (1.508%)
      These probabilities sum to 5.58%.
    • Alternatively (and this will be less rigorous and more open to variance in the data), we can look at the observed probabilities of each duration of negative growth:
        ◦ P(Two consecutive periods) = 7/285 = 2.456%
        ◦ P(Three consecutive periods) = 2/284 = 0.7042%
        ◦ P(Four consecutive periods) = 1/283 = 0.3534%
      These numbers are similar to the 14.34% to the power of 2, 3 or 4, respectively. But they’re bigger. That’s because of the correlation I mentioned above – negative growth quarters tend to follow each other; they’re clumped.
      Then, if 2019 involves 2+ consecutive periods of growth, there are three probabilities: 2 periods, 3 periods, or 4 periods. Simply summing the probabilities gets us to 3.514%. Not far off of the previous estimate – but I wouldn’t put too much stock into this number, because of the low sample sizes of 3-4 consecutive period making sound probability estimates difficult. On the other hand
    • If you consider that, simply put, over 73 years, there has been 10 periods of 2+ quarter growth; the probability of going into one of these in 2019 is 13.70%. If you reduce this by a quarter (as entering in Q4 doesn’t count for the question), you get 10.27%.
    • Averaging this with my 5.58% estimate gives 7.925%. Adjusting up and down
    • Given points 4 – 7 in my first paragraph, the period we’re in today doesn’t share the characteristics common to periods of negative growth. So I will adjust our estimate down. It’s tricky to calculate exactly how much, as any given group of four periods is inherently artificial. But the correlation between years is 36% (see 6), and in 70-80% of 2+ negative-growth periods the conditions are worse than today. So reducing the probability by about 30% seems roughly correct.
    • So my call is 7.925% * 0.7 = 5.548%
